repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
The whole cygdb construct is quite messy and a faulty installation is hard to debug because the error messages don't really hint at the problem.
This PR slightly improves the situation.

comment_data.body: Why not re-raise the exception here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -45,17 +45,22 @@ def make_command_file(path_to_debug_info, prefix_code='', no_import=False):
             set print pretty on
 
             python
-            # Activate virtualenv, if we were launched from one
-            import os
-            virtualenv = os.getenv('VIRTUAL_ENV')
-            if virtualenv:
-                path_to_activate_this_py = os.path.join(virtualenv, 'bin', 'activate_this.py')
-                print("gdb command file: Activating virtualenv: %s; path_to_activate_this_py: %s" % (
-                    virtualenv, path_to_activate_this_py))
-                with open(path_to_activate_this_py) as f:
-                    exec(f.read(), dict(__file__=path_to_activate_this_py))
-
-            from Cython.Debugger import libcython, libpython
+            from traceback import print_exc
+            try:
+                # Activate virtualenv, if we were launched from one
+                import os
+                virtualenv = os.getenv('VIRTUAL_ENV')
+                if virtualenv:
+                    path_to_activate_this_py = os.path.join(virtualenv, 'bin', 'activate_this.py')
+                    print("gdb command file: Activating virtualenv: %s; path_to_activate_this_py: %s" % (
+                        virtualenv, path_to_activate_this_py))
+                    with open(path_to_activate_this_py) as f:
+                        exec(f.read(), dict(__file__=path_to_activate_this_py))
+                from Cython.Debugger import libcython, libpython
+            except Exception as ex:
+                print("There was an error in Python code originating from the file ''' + str(__file__) + '''")
+                print("It used the Python interpreter " + str(sys.executable))
+                print_exc()

comment_data.body: Is `__file__` really the right file to report here? Or should it point at the virtualenv (if any) that it just tried to initialise?

comment_data.body:
print_exc gives a better error message than raising:
Example: I added a raise ValueErrror("test") to libpython.py
Without re-raising we get:

```
> There was an error in Python code originating from the file /home/volker/Sync/git/cython/Cython/Debugger/Cygdb.py
> It used the Python interpreter /usr/bin/python
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "<string>", line 12, in <module>
>   File "/home/volker/Sync/git/cython/Cython/Debugger/libcython.py", line 60, in <module>
>     from Cython.Debugger import libpython
>   File "/home/volker/Sync/git/cython/Cython/Debugger/libpython.py", line 57, in <module>
>     raise ValueError("test")
> ValueError: test
> /tmp/tmpv_wmeqcm:28: Error in sourced command file:
> Undefined command: "cy".  Try "help".
> (gdb) 
```
With re-raising and without print_exc() we get:

```
> There was an error in Python code originating from the file /home/volker/Sync/git/cython/Cython/Debugger/Cygdb.py
> It used the Python interpreter /usr/bin/python
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "<string>", line 18, in <module>
> ValueError: test
> /tmp/tmphlesqyrq:26: Error in sourced command file:
> Error while executing Python code.
> (gdb) 
```
But I just realised that exit(1) will stop gdb wich is what we want. I added a commit.

comment_data.body:
I think that `__file__` is correct. I installed it in a virtualenv and it printed:
/home/volker/Documents/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Debugger/Cygdb.py
which is exactly what we want.

Note that the `__file__ `is outside of the triple quotes.

comment_data.body:
Someone commented "Did you actually try this? I don't think it inserts the interpreter name here.", but I can't find find the comment.
Yes I tried this. interpreter is the variable defined by interpreter = interpreter_file.read() . Note that this is not the current python interpreter (that would be sys.executable) but the interpreter that compiled the users .pyx files.
Example:
```
$ python2 setup.py build_ext --inplace   
...
$ cygdb . -- -q --args python main.py
Reading symbols from python...
(No debugging symbols found in python)
/usr/bin/python2 was not compiled with debug symbols (or it was stripped). Some functionality may not work (properly).
(gdb)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -79,8 +85,8 @@ def make_command_file(path_to_debug_info, prefix_code='', no_import=False):
                     gdb.lookup_type('PyModuleObject')
                 except RuntimeError:
                     sys.stderr.write(
-                        'Python was not compiled with debug symbols (or it was '
-                        'stripped). Some functionality may not work (properly).\\n')
+                        "''' + interpreter + ''' was not compiled with debug symbols (or it was "

comment_data.body: Yeah, my bad. I failed to understand the string quoting in the diff. All fine.

commit.message: If your installation is faulty, cygdb will now print the filepath of the code that caused an exception.
If a bug in cygdb occurs, the path of the python interpreter will be printed for better debugging.
Split long line to make tests pass.
gdb will now exit if cygdb raises.
Cygdb now tells you the path of the python binary that was wrongfully stripped.

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Better diagnostics for faulty installations.
